div.head: To my Sonne BROME and his. Lasse.
div.l: VVHich, then of Both shall I commend?
Or Thee (that art my Sonne and Friend)
Or Her, by Thee begot▪ A Girle
Twice worth the Cleopatrian Pearle.
No: 'tis not fit for Me to Grace
Thee, who art Mine; and to thy Face.

Yet I could say, the merries •
Mayd
Among the Nine, for Thee has luyd
A Ghyrlond by; and Iieres to see
Pied Ideots teare the Daphnean Tree;
Putting their Eyes out with those Boughes
With which Shee bids me deck thy Browes.
But what I bring shall crowne thy Daughter
(My Grand child) who (though full of laughter)
Not Lumpish-Cold, as is her Clime •
By Phoebus Lyre, Thy Northern Lasse
Our Southern proudest Beauties passe:
Be Iouiall with thy Braynes (her Mother)
And helpe her (Dick) to such Another.
